title: Quantum Tic-Tac-Toe
subtitle: Experience the Laws of Quantum Mechanics Through Strategic Gameplay

firstSquare.title: Your Turn, {{player}}!
firstSquare.action: What You Need to Do Now:
firstSquare.actionDesc: Select the first square where you want to place your quantum mark
firstSquare.whyDesc: Your mark {{moveId}} will enter an amazing quantum superposition state - it will exist in two different squares at the same moment! Just like how qubits work in real quantum computers.
firstSquare.next: After selecting the first square, you'll need to choose a second square to complete your quantum move. Think carefully about the positions of both squares - can they form a potential winning line?

secondSquare.title: Complete Your Move, {{player}}
secondSquare.action: What You Need to Do Now:
secondSquare.actionDesc: Select the second square to complete your quantum move and enter your mark into superposition
secondSquare.whyDesc: After selecting the second square, your quantum mark will actually exist in both squares at once until collapse occurs. This is the power of quantum superposition!
secondSquare.tip: Choose the second square wisely! Try to create potential winning lines with both squares. Remember: you can also share your opponent's squares to create quantum entanglement and control future collapses.

collapse.title: Quantum Collapse Moment!
collapse.whatDesc: A cycle has formed in the entanglement network! This means a closed loop of entangled moves has been completed, and now all quantum states linked to this cycle must be 'measured' to collapse into definite classical positions.
collapse.creator: Player {{player}} completed the cycle with their last move
collapse.action: What You Need to Do Now:
collapse.actionDesc: {{player}}, you now have the power to choose how the quantum states collapse! Choose wisely - your decision will determine where each quantum mark settles to become a fixed classical mark.
collapse.whyDesc: In real quantum mechanics, when a cycle of entangled states forms, a logical paradox occurs that forces the system to collapse and stabilize. This reflects the 'quantum measurement' principle where observation forces particles to choose a definite state. In our game, the player who didn't create the cycle acts as the 'observer' who determines the measurement outcome!
collapse.optionsDesc: Each option below represents a different way the quantum moves can collapse. Study the options carefully and choose what best fits your strategy - do you want to form a winning line? Or do you want to prevent your opponent from winning?
collapse.chooserNote: Note: The player opposite to whoever created the cycle always chooses how to collapse - this adds deep strategic dimension to the game!

victory.title: Well-Deserved Victory!
victory.explanation: Three classical marks in a row! The quantum superposition states have finally collapsed to form a winning configuration. Excellent play and strategic thinking!
victory.simultaneousDesc: Both players got 3 in a row! The winner is determined by whose winning line contains the earliest move.
victory.earliestMove: {{player}} wins because their winning line contains the earliest move

draw.title: Quantum Draw!
draw.explanation: The board is completely full without either player achieving three consecutive classical marks. All quantum uncertainties have been resolved, but the strategic balance between you was perfect! Amazing game from both sides.

introBanner.title: Quantum Computing: The Future of Technology
introBanner.description: Quantum computing exploits the strange laws of quantum mechanics like superposition and quantum entanglement to solve complex mathematical problems that are impossible for traditional computers to solve even if they ran for millions of years. It's not just faster computers, but a completely different way of processing information!

hero.title: Quantum Computing
hero.subtitle: Discover the technology that will change the world

what.title: What is Quantum Computing?
what.description: Quantum computing harnesses the strange laws of quantum mechanics to process information in ways impossible for classical computers. Instead of bits that are either 0 or 1, quantum computers use qubits that can be both at once — enabling them to solve in minutes what would take supercomputers millions of years.

classical.title: Classical Computer
classical.point2: Processes one calculation at a time

quantum.title: Quantum Computer
quantum.point2: Processes millions of calculations at once

superposition.title: Superposition
superposition.description: A qubit can exist in multiple states at the same time — like being in two places at once, until you observe it.

entanglement.title: Entanglement
entanglement.description: Two qubits become connected. Change one, and the other instantly changes too — no matter how far apart they are.

measurement.title: Measurement
measurement.description: When you observe a qubit, it 'collapses' from many possibilities into one definite state.

inside.title: Inside a Quantum Computer
inside.subtitle: The giant structure isn't the computer — it's just keeping the tiny chip cold!

cooling.title: Cooling System
cooling.point1: Size of an entire room (3 meters tall)
cooling.point2: Cools to -273°C — 100x colder than outer space!
cooling.point3: Takes days to reach the required temperature
cooling.point4: Any tiny vibration destroys the calculations
cooling.point5: Costs millions of dollars to build and operate

chip.title: Quantum Chip
chip.point1: Size of a fingernail or small coin
chip.point4: Any light or sound ruins the computations
chip.point5: This tiny chip IS the actual quantum computer

inside.insight: The giant golden structure exists only to protect the tiny chip inside. Without extreme cooling, qubits lose their quantum properties in microseconds!

medicine.title: Drug Discovery
medicine.description: Simulating molecular interactions to design new medicines — what takes years could take days

finance.title: Financial Modeling
finance.description: HSBC improved bond trading predictions by 34% using quantum computing in 2025

security.title: Cryptography
security.description: Building unbreakable quantum encryption for secure communications

optimization.title: Logistics & Optimization
optimization.description: Ford reduced scheduling time from 30 minutes to under 5 using quantum optimization

cta.title: Experience Quantum Mechanics
cta.description: Try these concepts yourself in our interactive quantum game

classic.title: Classic Tic-Tac-Toe
classic.desc: One mark, one square, simple and direct.

quantum.title: Quantum Tic-Tac-Toe
quantum.desc: One mark in TWO squares at once — until it collapses!

rule1.title: The Quantum Move
rule1.desc: On your turn, place your mark in TWO different squares. Your mark exists in both places at the same time — this is called superposition. Each move gets a subscript number (X₁, O₂, X₃...) to track the order.
rule1.caption: X₁ exists in both squares simultaneously — connected by quantum entanglement!

rule2.title: Entanglement
rule2.desc: Entanglement happens when a player places their mark in a square that already contains another mark. Now these marks are connected — what happens to one affects the other!
rule2.because: X₁ and O₂ share square 2. They cannot both collapse there — only one can stay!
rule2.if1: If X₁ collapses to square 2 → O₂ must go to square 5
rule2.if2: If O₂ collapses to square 2 → X₁ must go to square 1

rule3.title: The Cycle
rule3.desc: A cycle forms when entangled marks create a closed loop. When you can trace from one mark back to itself through shared squares — that's a cycle! A cycle triggers immediate collapse.
rule3.cycleExplanation: X₁ ↔ O₂ ↔ X₃ ↔ X₁ forms a closed loop!

rule4.title: The Collapse
rule4.desc: When a cycle forms, the player who did NOT create it gets to choose where the first mark collapses. Then all other marks collapse automatically in a chain reaction!
rule4.chooserExplanation: X created the cycle (Move 3), so O decides the collapse
rule4.bestChoice: O chooses Option 1 — she gets the strategic center square!

rule5.title: Winning
rule5.desc: Get three COLLAPSED marks in a row (horizontal, vertical, or diagonal) to win. Quantum marks in superposition don't count — only classical collapsed marks!
rule5.caption: Three collapsed X marks in a row — victory!

special.title: ⚡ Special Case: Simultaneous Win
special.desc: Sometimes when marks collapse, both players complete a row at the same time! When this happens, the player whose winning mark has the LOWER subscript number wins.
special.tip: X₃ beats O₄ because 3 < 4. The earlier move has priority — placing marks early matters!
